hawaiian_text: A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a, i ia wā ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi  kumamāhiku i nā māla ‘uala a Puali‘i. ‘O ke kino o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua  kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e, ‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona  ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō. A hiki lākou i ua māla  ‘uala, kēnā akula ia i nā keiki, “E huhuki i ka pu‘e  me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana.” Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi  mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e.
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: While Puali'i was away fishing, at that time Nāmakaokapāo'o went with sixteen children to Puali'i's sweet potato patches. Nāmakaokapāo'o's body at that time was incredibly small, not even two and a half feet tall, and his sickness was not cured, he was still ailing. When they arrived at the sweet potato patch, he said to the children, "Pull out the sweet potato vines and leaves completely from the ground, don't leave any growing." However, the children were afraid, so they remained still by the sweet potatoes and did not pull out the vines.
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary:
• This paragraph provides further insight into Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's character and his influence on others, specifically children. 
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is described as having an incredibly small body and not being fully cured of his sickness, suggesting that he might still be in a state of vulnerability or weakness. 
– The fact that he is accompanied by sixteen children (he 'umi-kumamāhiku) to Pua-li'i's sweet potato patches suggests that he might be gathering a group to carry out a task or cause some sort of disruption. 
• The name Pua-li'i can be broken down into Pua- (child/descendant) and -li'i (chief/chiefly line), suggesting a connection to or descent from a chiefly lineage. 
– Puali'i's absence (hala 'o Puali'i i ka lawai'a) due to fishing activities implies that he might be preoccupied with providing for his family or community, leaving his sweet potato patches unattended and vulnerable to disruption by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and the children. 
• The instructions given by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o to the children to pull out the sweet potato vines and leaves completely from the ground (e huhuki i ka pu'e me ka lau 'uala ā pau loa i luna) can be seen as an act of destruction or chaos, possibly symbolizing a rejection of traditional practices or the existing social order. 
– The children's fear (maka'u nō ua keiki) and refusal to carry out Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's instructions (kāohi mālie nō ma ka 'uala, 'a'ohe huhuki i ka pu'e) suggest that they might be aware of the potential consequences of such actions or that they are loyal to Pua-li'i and his property. 
• This event could be seen as an allegory for the transition from the 'Ai Kapu era to a more modern or progressive time. 
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's actions, though destructive, might represent a necessary step towards change and growth, while Pua-li'i's adherence to traditional practices and property rights might symbolize the resistance to such change. 
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o can be broken down into Nā-maka- (the eyes of) and -o-ka-pāo'o (the pāo'o fish), possibly suggesting a connection to intuition, insight, or spiritual guidance, which could be guiding his actions. 
• The cultural context of this passage is likely rooted in the 'Ai Kapu era, a period of Hawaiian history characterized by a complex system of rules and prohibitions. 
– The 'Ai Kapu era was marked by a strong emphasis on tradition, social hierarchy, and spiritual practices, which might be reflected in Pua-li'i's fishing activities and his concern for his sweet potato patches. 
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's actions, on the other hand, might represent a challenge to these traditional practices and social norms, potentially symbolizing a shift towards a more modern or Westernized way of life. 
• The significance of sweet potatoes (uala) in this passage should not be overlooked. 
– Sweet potatoes were a staple crop in ancient Hawai'i and played a crucial role in the traditional Hawaiian diet and economy. 
– The destruction of the sweet potato patches by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o could be seen as a metaphor for the disruption of traditional ways of life and the need for adaptation to changing circumstances.

reference_translation: When Puali‘i left to go fishing, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  came with seventeen other children to the sweet  potato patches of Puali‘i. The body of   Nāmakaokapāo‘o at the time was very small, just  two and a half feet tall. His penis was not yet fully  grown and was dangling. When the kids got to the   sweet potato patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o told the  other kids, “Rip out all of the sweet potato leaves. Don’t leave anything growing.” The children were  afraid and hesitated when they reached the  tubers, and they did not pull those out of the  mound.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 5:**• While Pua-li‘i was away fishing, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  came with 17 other children (perhaps all boys) to the  2 sweet potato patches. The reason they came to the  patches is not stated immediately, but it appears the  reason was to play. The 17 friends of Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o seem to represent the Hawaiian people as a  whole (or perhaps a group of individuals the  storyteller thinks poorly of) allegorically and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o seems to represent a progressive minded Hawaiian.  • Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is described at this point of the  story as very small, perhaps 2 feet tall, and that his  penis was not yet fully grown and dangling, likely  meaning he was not wearing a malo.  – The lack of a malo on a boy is descriptive of the  child being too young to wear one. In ‘Ai Kapu  culture, when boys are deemed to be physically  able for chores and work to help sustain the family,  they would go through rites to thrust them into an  age of productive work to help support the family  demonstrated by wearing a malo on a daily basis. It  was a sign of maturity (footnote: Pukui, Haertig, Lee (1972:114) “For the *keiki lewalewa*—usually shortened to *lewalewa*—was yet a “dangler.” A small boy, so young his penis dangled. As a dangler, he wore no  *malo* (loincloth) and he lived and ate with the women. For he was yet *poke‘o*, too young to join the men. ¶ When the little dangler became six or seven years old, his status  changed in one decisive ceremony. This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The children demonstrate hesitancy and  destroy the vines and leaves of the sweet potatoes,  but do not dig out the tubers from under the ground. – This likely demonstrates a social rhetorical   commentary about or critique of the ‘Ai Kapu  culture as a whole, that it was worthy of   destruction, with its segregation of men and  women and emphasis on heirarchy, perhaps a  justification for abandoning the culture in 1819\.  The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;
